results.title: Access News greatest hits 2000. Part 2
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description:
Access News Greatest Hits 2000 (Part 2 of 2)
SKA TV’s Access News is a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
Giving light to perspectives or issues otherwise not seen, stories range from front-line coverage of anti-globalisation protests to satirical critiques of commercial media.
‘Greatest Hits 2000’ is a compilation of 15 of Access News’s best stories from the year 2000.
Highlights from part 2:
Fortress Goolengook : After having their camp destroyed by loggers, forest blockaders in the heart of East Gippsland’s Goolengook forest build an elaborate fortress (including drawbridge!) to ensure their safety against further attacks.
Viva Falantil : A tour through a newly-independent East Timor, still shell-shocked and facing an uncertain future. This story examines the possibilities for and obstacles to building a democratic nation.
Herald Sun Occupation : During the World Economic Forum (WEF) held in Melbourne in September 2000, a group of protesters went to the Herald Sun newspaper to voice their concern the paper’s exceptionally biased coverage of the protests outside the WEF.
results.creator_credit_for_label: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr

results.title: S.T.O.P. Surviving Time outside Prison
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: Awareness-raising report on the plight of ex-prisoners of Deer Park correctional facility to secure adequate support for women who have been released from prison. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Emu Spew
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: Report on the efforts of the Adnyamathanha people, traditional landowners of the Northern Flinders Rangers to stop the Beverly Uranium Mining Project. The report also covers police action against the protestors and the unsafe method the mining company are using to extract the uranium. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Guinea pigs
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “About Animals”.
Children learn that guinea pigs are affectionate animals who seem to like being with people and are easy to care for and handle. Basic facts about selective breeding are introduced as the children observe the varied colourings and markings of guinea pigs.

results.title: A Day for Being Irish
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
Every year since 1606 the town of Ballycastle in County Antrim, Northern Ireland has held the Lammas Fair to which people come to trade, barter and generally have a good time. Originally the fair was set up for the Scottish overlords of the time to trade their horses for black cattle and other goods that they needed. The nearby islanders of Rathlin also participate in the fair by selling seaweed.

results.title: Carnival in France
results.creator_credit: Barry Sloane, Joy Barrow and Barinder Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “A World of Festivals”.
For two months before Easter the French town of Limoux celebrates the end of winter with the oldest continuous carnival in France. As well as showing preparations for the carnival and the carnival itself the video also visits the neighbouring medieval town of Carcassonne and shows the making of the unique sparkling wine of the area, Blanquette de Limoux.

results.title: The Bat and the rainbow
results.creator_credit: Educational Media Australia, David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Australian National University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Aboriginal legends”.
The Bat’s wife was stolen from him by Rainbow. To get her back Bat mortally wounds the sleeping Rainbow. Bleeding badly, Rainbow rolls into the waterhole where he can still be found. Occasionally, during wet weather, Rainbow rises from the waterhole and stretches his handsome body across the sky. This title is also available in a compilation with two other legends under the title “Aboriginal legends. No. 3” Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
